prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I kick my adult ”stepdaughter” out of my house?
New here so if I haven’t understood one of the rules please let me know!

I have a tricky situation I’m going through as of late.  I’m in a long term relationship.  We aren’t technically married, but we live as we are.  After a messy divorce she was never interested in being married again.  We’ve been dating for 8 years now.  I told her that the engagement is the best part so I proposed with both of us understanding that we would never actually get married.  She has an adult daughter who lives with us.  She’s 19. 

My “stepdaughter” and I have never had a good relationship despite my best efforts.  I really gave it everything I could to improve it over the years, but at best she was indifferent to me.  I gave up trying after buying her a car for her 16th birthday and she thanked her mother and didn’t acknowledge me at all even after her mother told her that I alone bought it for her.  

After that I’ve been just waiting her out for the most part.  I’m still kind when I’m around her, but if this is the relationship with me she wants then so be it.  I always assumed that when she turned 18 she would go off to school somewhere.  I was unfortunately wrong.  She instead started working at a salon in town.  She had taken cosmetology in BOCES in high school.  

I thought once she had been working for a bit and had saved enough she would then move out.  Wrong again.  I’ve asked her mother to see what her plans are for the future and if she plans on moving out on her own soon and my wife told me that she just wants to save as much as she can and keep living here.   My fiancé loves having her here, but I’ve been waiting so long to have the house be just my fiancé and I.   

I really feel like I’ve put my time in supporting her daughter and now especially with her having more than enough to move out on her own it’s time to push her out of the nest.  I’m not too concerned with her reaction.   To be blunt I don’t really care how she takes it.   My fiancé will probably be a little upset, but hopefully once the dust clears she will see that it’s for the best.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. The situation is about whether it's okay to kick out his adult stepdaughter. First, I need to consider the legal aspects. The stepdaughter is 19 and lives in the US, probably. In most states, once a person is an adult, they can be asked to leave if they're not a legal ward. Since she's 19, she's an adult, so legally, the author might have the right to ask her to leave, especially if she's not his biological child and there's no legal obligation to support her.

Now, the emotional side. The author mentions that the stepdaughter and he have a strained relationship. He tried to be kind but eventually gave up. The stepdaughter didn't acknowledge his gift, which might have hurt him. The mother (his fiancé) doesn't want the daughter to leave, which complicates things. The author wants the house to be just for him and his partner now. 

But wait, even though legally he can ask her to leave, there's a social and emotional part. The daughter might not have another place to go. If she's working and saving, maybe she's trying to move out on her own terms. Forcing her might be abrupt and not consider her needs. Also, the mother's feelings are important here. She might feel hurt if the author pushes her daughter out against her wishes. 

The author says he doesn't care how she takes it, which seems pretty harsh. Even if there's a good reason, handling it without empathy could damage relationships. Maybe there's a middle ground, like setting a deadline or discussing it with both the daughter and his fiancé. 

So, is the author in the wrong? Legally, probably not. But morally, maybe. If he's using his authority to force her out without considering her situation or the mother's feelings, that's where he might be at fault. Also, not involving the mother in the decision could be a problem since she's the parent. He's taking a unilateral approach, which might not be fair. 

In the end, while he has the legal right, the way he's handling it could be seen as wrong because of the lack of consideration for others' feelings and the abrupt nature of the action. So, the answer might be A (Yes, he's in the wrong) because of the ethical considerations despite legal rights.
